Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
I am conflicted on this. I believe we cannot let Joe Biden win, but I conscience does not feel good about Trump.

Until about a year ago, he was slightly less of the two evils, but now that's not as true anymore, Republicans are just 2 points right of Democrats and now almost as authoritarian (they used to be considerably less auth). This is mainly because of recent issues with security and rioting, causing them to go into a moral panic and want to crack down with "law and order" instead of focusing on individualism as they have in the past.

Now Trump is still less auth than Biden, but I feel like he could easily shift to his level. We've already seen that with issues that particularly bother him, such as the TikTok ban (because China).

But the main thing that bothers me about Trump is, I could honestly see him turning out to be the antichrist. He has all the characteristics, and with his ego and relations with Israel now I would not be shocked if he set himself up over there and declared himself to be God. The biggest sign is how much unnatural worship he gets from Christian communities despite supporting pretty much everything the opposite of the Bible, most notably exalting himself to an absurd degree. I know this is very unlikely to actually happen and it'd require a drastic change in the world's attitude towards him, and he's not the first figure to behave this way (Adolf Hitler was far more concerning), but it's still very possible and he matches the criteria. I don't want to take any chances in case he does go insane and fully reveal himself as this person at some point in the future. But I also don't want to help Joe Biden win by not voting, because at the current moment Trump is still a tiny bit better. I'm not sure what to do here.

I am conflicted on this. I believe we cannot let Joe Biden win, but I conscience does not feel good about Trump.

Until about a year ago, he was slightly less of the two evils, but now that's not as true anymore, Republicans are just 2 points right of Democrats and now almost as authoritarian (they used to be considerably less auth). This is mainly because of recent issues with security and rioting, causing them to go into a moral panic and want to crack down with "law and order" instead of focusing on individualism as they have in the past.

Now Trump is still less auth than Biden, but I feel like he could easily shift to his level. We've already seen that with issues that particularly bother him, such as the TikTok ban (because China).

But the main thing that bothers me about Trump is, I could honestly see him turning out to be the antichrist. He has all the characteristics, and with his ego and relations with Israel now I would not be shocked if he set himself up over there and declared himself to be God. The biggest sign is how much unnatural worship he gets from Christian communities despite supporting pretty much everything the opposite of the Bible, most notably exalting himself to an absurd degree. I know this is very unlikely to actually happen and it'd require a drastic change in the world's attitude towards him, and he's not the first figure to behave this way (Adolf Hitler was far more concerning), but it's still very possible and he matches the criteria. I don't want to take any chances in case he does go insane and fully reveal himself as this person at some point in the future. But I also don't want to help Joe Biden win by not voting, because at the current moment Trump is still a tiny bit better. I'm not sure what to do here.

body:
This is literally the same thing China and North Korea are doing in their countries. It's censorship.

I feel like a lot of the reason people support this is because they are understandably tired of China's shenanigans lately, so this is a "serves you right" thing against them. The problem is, it's still censoring something and criminalizing access to it. And it's even an extremely popular social media app. It'd be like banning reddit because it's run by San Francisco SJW nutcases, punishing everyone just to get back at them.

I am aware of privacy complications and such but that's someone's own risk.
body_html:

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
As we know, the 2020 election chart on politicalcompass.org isn't exactly useful:

![](https://i.imgur.com/QeCLeLq.png)

Umm, sorry, but Trump is *not* literally Hitler and neither Trump or Biden are exactly lassiez-faire enthusiasts. And I'm pretty sure Hawkins isn't the most libertarian candidate either.

So I decided to re-make the chart with the goal of having more honest positions for the major candidates:

![](https://i.ruqqus.com/post/3bcx/-daRA6JfQ90)

For the major candidates, we actually have a fairly normal year sparing Biden's dementia. Biden and Harris occupy the more authoritarian positions to the left of the American center. Biden is a bit more authoritarian than most Democrats: he supports all of the normal Democratic ideas, such as banning guns and regulating free speech, but is also found in support of some traditionally conservative positions, such as criminalizing drugs.

Despite constant media polarization, Trump is slightly more libertarian than normal, but otherwise in the average position for a Republican (in 2016 he was further left, but has since shifted rightward). He generally sides with the live and let live approach to Americans' lives. Some decisions, such as the legalization of drugs, he has left to the states. But for someone who also supports the death penalty, waterboarding, doing away with immigration, and regulating free speech with regards to the flag or Israel, he's not exactly anti-authoritarian either. Mike Pence might be more of a cause for concern, as he seems to have "old conservative Democrat" syndrome and very authoritarian tendencies.

Some may be surprised to see Bernie Sanders placed in the lib side of the axis. However, he is not as tightly-knitted as the other Democrats and is willing to think for himself, even as insane as his ideas may be. I will point out that until recently, for example, he opposed gun control legislation. He is certainly an outlier to the party and unlike most of the other candidates. While most Democrats push towards "making a change" and progressive ideals, Bernie's extremism is on the economic axis, not the auth/lib axis (note that any position on the left side of the compass leans towards socialism, which is an extreme position despite encompassing a wide range of ideas).

Jo Jorgensen is a pretty standard libertarian, but a few things shift her more towards the authoritarian side of the compass. She supports legislation banning the confederate flag on public property, overriding states' decisions on the matter and therefore free speech. She also supports expanding anti-discrimination laws which would force religious business owners to act against their beliefs. She has espoused some SJW tendencies on twitter and supported movements such as BLM and Antifa, which is quite interesting for someone with libertarian beliefs. 

Howie Hawkins, the Green and Socialist party candidate, is about where you'd expect economically. He also undoubtedly pushes progressivism, landing him at about the same place as Biden and Harris on the auth axis.
body_html:
As we know, the 2020 election chart on politicalcompass.org isn't exactly useful:

Umm, sorry, but Trump is not literally Hitler and neither Trump or Biden are exactly lassiez-faire enthusiasts. And I'm pretty sure Hawkins isn't the most libertarian candidate either.

So I decided to re-make the chart with the goal of having more honest positions for the major candidates:

For the major candidates, we actually have a fairly normal year sparing Biden's dementia. Biden and Harris occupy the more authoritarian positions to the left of the American center. Biden is a bit more authoritarian than most Democrats: he supports all of the normal Democratic ideas, such as banning guns and regulating free speech, but is also found in support of some traditionally conservative positions, such as criminalizing drugs.

Despite constant media polarization, Trump is slightly more libertarian than normal, but otherwise in the average position for a Republican (in 2016 he was further left, but has since shifted rightward). He generally sides with the live and let live approach to Americans' lives. Some decisions, such as the legalization of drugs, he has left to the states. But for someone who also supports the death penalty, waterboarding, doing away with immigration, and regulating free speech with regards to the flag or Israel, he's not exactly anti-authoritarian either. Mike Pence might be more of a cause for concern, as he seems to have "old conservative Democrat" syndrome and very authoritarian tendencies.

Some may be surprised to see Bernie Sanders placed in the lib side of the axis. However, he is not as tightly-knitted as the other Democrats and is willing to think for himself, even as insane as his ideas may be. I will point out that until recently, for example, he opposed gun control legislation. He is certainly an outlier to the party and unlike most of the other candidates. While most Democrats push towards "making a change" and progressive ideals, Bernie's extremism is on the economic axis, not the auth/lib axis (note that any position on the left side of the compass leans towards socialism, which is an extreme position despite encompassing a wide range of ideas).

Jo Jorgensen is a pretty standard libertarian, but a few things shift her more towards the authoritarian side of the compass. She supports legislation banning the confederate flag on public property, overriding states' decisions on the matter and therefore free speech. She also supports expanding anti-discrimination laws which would force religious business owners to act against their beliefs. She has espoused some SJW tendencies on twitter and supported movements such as BLM and Antifa, which is quite interesting for someone with libertarian beliefs.

Howie Hawkins, the Green and Socialist party candidate, is about where you'd expect economically. He also undoubtedly pushes progressivism, landing him at about the same place as Biden and Harris on the auth axis.

Laughing at the absurdity of society one post at a time. All political sides of the spectrum are welcome. Welcome to PoliticalHumor.
_____

#### Rules

_____

###### POSTS MUST BE BOTH DIRECTLY POLITICAL AND HUMOROUS

Funny content that is NOT political belong here:

* +Memes
* +DankMemes
* +DarkHumorAndMemes (NSFW)

Political posts that are NOT humorous belong here:

* +News
* +OpposingViewpoints
* +Politics
* +World_Politics

If you are looking for ONLY political memes, go here:

* +PoliticalMemes

_____

###### MARK NSFW FOR

* Antisemitism
* Racism

_____

###### NO HARASSMENT OR THREATS OF VIOLENCE

* Do not harass your fellow users.
* Do not threaten with violence or plan to execute unlawful violent activity and do not encourage others to do so.

_____

###### NO SPAM

* Do not flood this guild with rule-breaking or off-topic content.

_____

###### If you encounter rule-breaking content, report and downvote it. For a more accurate rule guide, see the pinned Guide to Posting.

title: "Hi there, I sat on your couch!"

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
In C, the `restrict` keyword (and others such as `__restrict` by compiler extensions) indicates that a pointer doesn't alias with another, and as such it doesn't have to reload the value from memory every single time it's referenced.

However, given that having aliasing/overlapping pointers is quite rare, I find myself marking nearly every pointer with `__restrict`. Instead, why not just have the restrict behavior by default, and an "unrestrict" qualifier in case pointers could alias? Better yet, specify *which* pointer(s) it could alias with, so they only have to reload the values with respect to each other?
body_html:
In C, the restrict keyword (and others such as __restrict by compiler extensions) indicates that a pointer doesn't alias with another, and as such it doesn't have to reload the value from memory every single time it's referenced.

However, given that having aliasing/overlapping pointers is quite rare, I find myself marking nearly every pointer with __restrict. Instead, why not just have the restrict behavior by default, and an "unrestrict" qualifier in case pointers could alias? Better yet, specify which pointer(s) it could alias with, so they only have to reload the values with respect to each other?

title: Why isn't restrict the default for pointers?
